0.sent: >Hotel California Fact: Sound is a vibration.

1.sent: Sound travels as a mechanical wave through a medium, and in space, there is no medium.

2.sent: So when my shuttle malfunctioned and the airlocks didn't keep the air in, I heard nothing.

3.sent: After the first whoosh of the air being sucked away, there was lightning, but no thunder.

4.sent: Eyes bulging in panic, but no screams.

6.sent: Such a relief to never again hear my crewmate Jesse natter about his girl back on Earth and that all-expenses-paid vacation-for-two she won last time he was on leave.

7.sent: I swore, if I ever had to see a photo of him in a skimpy bathing suit again, giving the camera a cheesy thumbs-up from a lounge chair on one of those white sandy beaches, I'd kiss a monkey.

9.sent: Fact: If, before all the air is sucked out of the ship, a person is so lucky to have stuffed him or herself into a space suit, that person has less than twenty-four hours to live.

10.sent: This is more than the person would have sans space suit.

11.sent: Me, I found a space suit, but it was statistically unlikely that I, and whomever else has followed suit (pun intended), would manage to repair our ship before the less-than-twenty-four hours are up; yes, studies have been done.

14.sent: About the time I was composing my last words in my head, trying not to think too much about what suffocating felt like, that's when I heard a bell.

15.sent: My first thought: I was going crazy.

16.sent: Twenty-four hours of silence (vacuum, remember); was I hallucinating noises now?

18.sent: It was a fine bell, reminiscent of ancient stone churches and the towering cathedrals I'd seen in documentaries.

19.sent: And accompanying the bell, I saw a light.

20.sent: Now, there were two things here that made ridiculously small amounts of sense.

21.sent: First, the whole in-a-vacuum why's-there-a-bell thing.

22.sent: Second, I was floating in the dark remnants of my broken ship, and any conceivable light sources were not within view; starlight is a distinctly different color and significantly less bright.

23.sent: These signals were the heralds of my saviors.

24.sent: The first words they said to me meant nothing.

25.sent: I wasn't listening; I didn't care; I was going to live; I was going to keep breathing.

26.sent: Next to those, nothing else mattered.

27.sent: The recycled air tasted sweet in my mouth, and all thoughts that crossed my mind were cheap metaphors about life-giving substances and how breathing was like sex, only better.

28.sent: (I reserved the right to revise this opinion later.)

29.sent: When I was done mentally exclaiming over my impossible rescue, I looked around.

30.sent: The ship, it was odd and old, either so outdated or so heavily modified that I couldn't tell what make it was, and somehow, the crew standing around me fit the same description, a singularly atypical amalgamation of folk.

31.sent: And me, I guess I was one more piece in their puzzle.

32.sent: I was one more scrap to weld onto the rest, one more stranded survivor who was found.

33.sent: I was now one of them.

35.sent: The survivors of the unfortunate accidents, the catastrophic malfunctions, the fateful crashes: this is us.

36.sent: Floating alone, each of us facing the silence of the vacuum, we were found.

37.sent: Once found, we can never be lost.

41.sent: You do this a lot?” A woman, introduced as Tiffany and neither tall nor beautiful, shrugged.

43.sent: Why didn't you save them?” As much as Jesse had irritated me, I didn't like the picture my brain drew of him floating in his grave, body swollen and bloated.

44.sent: Who would tell his girl how he had died?

46.sent: Jefferson, he called himself, clean-shaven and smart, a picture of the perfect entrepreneur.

47.sent: An opportunist and a businessman, that was Jefferson.

48.sent: “We're selective about our passengers,” he continued.

50.sent: They didn't.” Tiffany, she looked at the captain, grinned and flipped her greasy brown locks over her shoulder.

52.sent: “Come on,” she said, before I could say anything else, “let's get you settled in.” No time for questions.

54.sent: The ship had all the usual accoutrements (artificial gravity, tastefully painted walls, sound dampeners to keep the noise of the engines from driving the crew batshit insane, recycled air systems), and a few less-usual: lush carpeting, lighting that was decorative as well as functional, spacious corridors.

55.sent: The occasional painting hung on the wall (generic landscapes and portraits of old people no one has ever met, primarily).

56.sent: Glimpses of elegant rooms down the branching hallways; music; voices; the aroma of real food.

58.sent: No seventy-two virgins, but it would do.

62.sent: It's not far; you're not going to get blisters.” “No, I meant, where's the ship going?

63.sent: What's our destination?” Tiffany, she stopped walking.

64.sent: She gave me a look, pitying and a little pleased that she got to be the one to share the news.

65.sent: “Honey,” she said, “You're going to be delighted.

68.sent: I died in those last moments, suffocating on my own exhaled breath, and this, this was my reward.

69.sent: Fact: The speed of sound in dry air at twenty degrees Celsius or sixty-eight degrees Fahrenheit is three hundred and forty-three meters per second, or one thousand one hundred twenty-five feet per second.

70.sent: It took me a couple days to realize I was, in fact, still alive.

71.sent: I mean, sure, I'd had my moment of elation when I had first realized I'd been rescued, but it didn't sink in.

72.sent: After watching my ship tear apart, after spending a good twenty-three hours floating in silence in the wreck, wondering whether I was currently facing stars belonging to the constellation Libra or the constellation Orion when those stars were viewed from Earth, wondering what it felt like to suffocate, and after the feeling that yes, I was in fact going to die alone in space had sunk in, it took time for that feeling to dissipate.

74.sent: After I realized this, I left my quarters.

75.sent: The lightscreen provided had informed me when and where official meals were taking place, but I hadn't bothered to acknowledge the invitations.

76.sent: It hadn't seemed relevant, somehow, given that I was still reeling over the explosion, the deaths of my crewmates, and the rescue.

77.sent: I've heard there are a number of stages of grief and shock; I guess I was working my way through them.

78.sent: Food was delivered to my quarters.

79.sent: Initially, I couldn't figure out why—I hadn't requested any be sent.

80.sent: Then I realized, someone must have noticed I hadn't left, and was nice enough to send food my way.

81.sent: The accompanying bottle of wine was a nice touch.

82.sent: I must have consumed it, too, because later on, the plates and the bottle were both empty.

83.sent: I spent a lot of time lying on my back on the bed, staring up at the little etched swirls in the ceiling, or slumped in the old-fashioned armchair, staring out the windows at the stars.

84.sent: I did a lot of staring and not moving.

85.sent: Man, was it good to be done with that stage.

86.sent: It was time to find out what hell looked like.

89.sent: We didn't pick up many passengers—just the select, special few, scattered here and there between the stars.

90.sent: But we were all on this ship, and we were on it together.

91.sent: Cliques form in any decent-sized group of people.

92.sent: Me, I was singled out by Sarah, an unassuming forty-something lady with a glass of champagne in one hand and the arm of a scrawny but tall blond man in the other.

93.sent: She sidled up to me as I was scooping little round crackers and what appeared to be a baked cilantro cream dip onto a plate.

94.sent: The plate, by the way, was already loaded with folded pieces of smoked pink fish, paprika-dusted deviled eggs, toothpicks stabbed through green vegetables and slices of cheese, and balls of meat smothered in a tomato-based sauce.

95.sent: Luxurious, even compared to the fare one would find in the high-class space stations and pleasure cruisers.

96.sent: Compared to what a mere engineer would get on your typical cargo ship, it was mouthwateringly, lip-smackingly gorgeous.

97.sent: I wondered if the food delivered to my quarters the past few days had been similarly amazing.

98.sent: I decided it couldn't have been.

99.sent: “Liking the taste of the sweet life, eh?

100.sent: I'm Sarah, and this is Alexis—you must be the new pickup.” She looked me over approvingly.

101.sent: “Come on, let's get you a glass of champagne.” I looked longingly at the slices of cheddar olive bread as she whisked me over to the bar, but didn't protest.

102.sent: The bar was manned by an expensive humanoid robot.

103.sent: It turned toward Sarah's wave and acknowledged her with a nod, moments later setting a fluted glass of sparkling liquid in front of her.

104.sent: I marveled at the robot's smoothness and coordination.

105.sent: Clearly, it was a high-end model.

106.sent: Sarah transferred the glass to my free hand and pulled me away from the bar for more introductions, with Alexis trailing after us.

107.sent: I spent the evening listening, mostly.

108.sent: Listening and stuffing my face with all the bits of fine food provided.

109.sent: No one minded; Sarah's inner circle was content to fill our circle of couches with plenty of chatter.

110.sent: Ray, a plump man who was grey where he wasn't bald.

111.sent: Zheng, short and dark and lean, with a very intense gaze.

112.sent: He made me a little uncomfortable.

113.sent: Kishori, petite, her hair strung out in a series of braids that reached nearly to her waist.

114.sent: I categorized them based on their appearances, hoping I'd be able to pick them out of the crowd again later.

115.sent: Most of their chatter was meaningless to me—stories of day-to-day activities, how so-and-so had been seen in so-and-so's table at lunch and my wasn't that a surprise, and why hadn't the chef concocted this delectable a selection of appetizers for the dance the other night, but of course those rolled meat pastries reminded one of the pastries back on Earth, didn't they, and this was somehow an interesting fact.

116.sent: After the first half-hour, I stopped expending effort to keep names and stories and gossip straight.

118.sent: I could have started asking questions, but I wanted to get my bearings first.

120.sent: I didn't bother trying to seek out a different group of potentially more interesting people, though.

121.sent: They all looked the same: clusters of social butterflies surrounded by the less apt, the hangers-on, the circle with whom the gossip was shared.

122.sent: I wondered at the ship instead.

123.sent: All the fine food and the ornamental lighting, it had to be exorbitantly pricey to maintain.

124.sent: If the barkeep was any indication, I suspected similarly high-class robots fulfilled other positions on the ship.

125.sent: How they were all powered was a mystery—as good as the technology got, a quality robot like that was still an energy sink.

126.sent: It was the brain, mostly; the amount of information the machine had to process to be able to function at the level it did ate up a lot of resources.

127.sent: Sarah's crowd took turns taking my champagne flute to the bar to be refilled, all seemingly pleased to have a new set of ears to talk at.

128.sent: I slowly returned my attention to the conversation and was pleasantly surprised to find that it had turned to a heated analysis of a recent abstract film—done in the style of old flatscreen movies—that I had seen during off-time at Geminia Station.

129.sent: By the end of the evening, when I finally followed the slow trickle of people out of the room, a satisfying haze had settled on my mind.

133.sent: The nagging questions about where the ship had come from and what its purpose in rescuing me was still nagged, but somehow, seemed less urgent.

134.sent: Did it truly matter what the ship's origin was and why Jefferson had saved me, if now, I was content?

135.sent: Fact: It's easy to fall into patterns.

136.sent: I would wake late, checking the clock on my room's lightscreen to make sure I hadn't slept through brunch.

137.sent: I would join the rest of the ship for meals, and I would take my turn in the weight room.

138.sent: I would watch old films on the entertainment screens, taking mental notes for later dinnertime discussions.

139.sent: I would immerse myself in new virtual reality flicks.

140.sent: I would attend afternoon dance classes, so that when the evening dances came around (modeled after the historical social gatherings of several hundred years prior), I would be less of an embarrassment to myself.

143.sent: I told myself that tonight, the observation period would end and I'd start puzzling out the ship's mystery.

144.sent: But I fell under the ship's sway.

145.sent: Bereft of my previous familiar life, I latched onto Kishori and Ray and Zheng, and Sarah with Alexis dragged along on her arm now and then (he was mostly her favorite dancing partner; she confided to us one night that his conversational skills left something to be desired).

146.sent: I smothered thoughts of friends back on Earth—this was my long-awaited vacation, my clean break and my temporary retreat; I'd try contacting those friends tomorrow.

147.sent: I continued to care little for shipwide gossip, but our discussions of films and flicks, old and new, brought out my artistic, story-loving, argumentative side, a side of me I'd tucked into a back storage compartment during my years as an engineer.

148.sent: It was a good life, if surreal.

149.sent: But I wasn't sure I wanted the dream stage to end.

151.sent: Days passed, weeks passed, but I couldn't tell if it had been months or years since I was rescued.

152.sent: All there was, all I remembered, was a blur.

153.sent: Gathering for drinks in the parlors, playing dress up with all the fine clothes I found in the closets (some of it modern, some of it period dress for special themed events), idling in the lounges.

154.sent: Now and then, a new face mingled in the crowd.

155.sent: Other faces washed out, fading into the backdrop of carpets and fake glass chandeliers and the muted hum of the engines.

156.sent: One of these evenings, we were gathered in the South Ballroom for post-dinner drinks, lounging on couches and watching other members of our populace move in circles on the dance floor.

157.sent: (The 'South' was in the title to suggest that there were more ballrooms.

159.sent: Sarah's circle had picked up another newcomer, Adrienne, a short blond girl who we all agreed was barely old enough to attend a traditional university back on Earth, let alone work on the ship in whose wreck Jefferson had found her.

160.sent: Maybe it was her curiosity, asking a question I should have asked long before, that turned the conversation serious; maybe there was just something special about that evening.

161.sent: Maybe we had all tired of the frivolity of our life, hitting some threshold or some breaking point.

162.sent: Regardless, when Adrienne asked what the ship's purpose was, we all gave it a measure of thought.

163.sent: We dredged up half-fledged theories and inchoate explanations, tossing these out the same way we pitched ideas about the art films.

164.sent: “I believe we'll see the end of the universe,” said Tiffany.

165.sent: Captain's cohort, she had a glass of orange-brown liquid in one hand; it might have been orange juice and some kind of berry liquor.

168.sent: She tilted her head, listening, not speaking.

169.sent: “Impossible,” said Zheng, sitting in the chair to her left.

170.sent: “We can't live that long.” “Maybe the universe will end sooner than you think,” said Jefferson.

171.sent: Yeah, the captain was there, with the rest of us.

172.sent: He didn't drink, but he made a point of mingling with all the various cliques.

173.sent: “Maybe we'll travel at the speed of light and we won't age,” said Sarah, setting her wine glass on the little round end table by her couch.

174.sent: “Maybe we're already traveling at the speed of light.” Tiffany, she nodded eagerly.

177.sent: Even if we were traveling at ninety-nine percent of the speed of light—that's assuming you ignore science and pretend that such a thing is possible, because it isn't—we'd still age.

178.sent: We'd just appear to age slower than people not traveling as fast as us.” “And?” said Sarah.

180.sent: Besides, I wouldn't mind being around forever.

182.sent: Keep their dreams alive.” “New hypothesis,” suggested Kishori, slipping into the conversation.

184.sent: In fact, the opposite: We're all going to die.” “Bleak,” commented Zheng.

185.sent: “But I like it.” He grinned at Sarah, who frowned.

186.sent: Ray took a drink from his glass of ice water, and shook his head.

187.sent: “We're all going to die, so what better thing to do than enjoy the time we have?” Kishori gestured to the bar, the carpets, the paintings.

188.sent: “All the luxuries money can buy.” Tiffany took a drink, thinking.

189.sent: “All the luxuries money can buy,” she echoed.

194.sent: “Think about it,” Kishori continued, “where else would we get the money to buy all this?” “Renegade smugglers.

195.sent: So what's our cargo, eh, captain?” Zheng joked, leaning back in his chair with his glass of wine.

196.sent: Jefferson shook his head and stood up.

197.sent: “I'll leave you to your speculation,” he said.

198.sent: A chorus of good nights followed him out the door.

199.sent: After the captain left, Zheng leaned in.

200.sent: He set his glass down on an end table, steepled his fingers together.

202.sent: “And I don't mean that you disgust me.

203.sent: No, we're the start of a rebellion.

204.sent: Did you hear what the captain said earlier?

205.sent: He means, we're going to change the future.

206.sent: The universe as we know it won't be the same.” “That's dumb,” said Sarah.

207.sent: “Wouldn't we know it if we were part of a rebellion?

209.sent: “The captain selected us for a reason.

210.sent: He has inside intelligence—how else would he know where to find us?

211.sent: He knows about us.” “That's still dumb,” said Sarah.

213.sent: Don't you remember, there's not exactly one big galactic government from which to steal information.” “I still like my idea,” said Tiffany.

214.sent: Me, I followed Adrienne's example and didn't speak up (fabricating excuses to myself to stay safely in gather-info observation mode), though I thought Zheng had a point.

215.sent: Jefferson didn't share how he found people.

216.sent: He didn't share how he knew exactly where the wrecks were, or why he saved some people but not others.

217.sent: But then again, no one asked.

218.sent: I guess we all figured, he knew what he was doing.

219.sent: He had been at this savior business longer than any of us.

220.sent: I wondered if Adrienne would ask about that.

221.sent: “We're going to mean something,” Zheng was saying.

222.sent: “What we do, rebelling against the oppression of the many governments that oppose us, we're going to leave a legacy.” He sounded certain.

224.sent: Ray, he shook his head, and broke the quiet he'd held most of the evening.

225.sent: “You've got it all wrong.” He looked from Sarah, to Adrienne, to Zheng, to Kishori and Tiffany, to me.

226.sent: “Obviously, we can't last longer than the rest of the universe.

228.sent: We're not even going to leave a legacy.

230.sent: All we're doing is eating and drinking and shitting, breathing and fucking and nothing important, ever.

231.sent: We aren't special.” “Again, bleak,” commented Zheng.

232.sent: Adrienne gestured for him to be quiet.

233.sent: She leaned forward, setting her elbows on the foot stool in front of her.

234.sent: “You never know when it will end,” Ray continued, not addressing any one of us in particular.

235.sent: “You can't hold on forever, even if you don't ever, ever want to forget.

236.sent: How long until the memories slip away?

237.sent: How long until all you remember is this, the ship, the thick red carpeting, the chandeliers, the empty conversations you hold with the other shells who used to be people?

238.sent: When your life, the reason you lived, the people and faces and places, the emotions you felt, who and what you loved, when all that is gone, faded, what will you have left?” I wondered how long Ray had been on this ship.

239.sent: I wondered why, if he had such an unpropitious outlook, he hadn't tried to change his situation.

240.sent: I wanted to ask, but he was still talking, and I was too self-conscious to interrupt.

241.sent: “You can try to hold on,” said Ray.

242.sent: “You can try and try and try.

243.sent: Repeat stories to yourself in the artificial night, sketch faces in your mind.

244.sent: You can make their names your mantra.

245.sent: But words, if you repeat them enough times, lose their meaning.

248.sent: Repeat it enough times, it's just a sound.

249.sent: No longer grounded.” Ray, he said, “If we last forever, if our eyes are the last eyes watching as the stars blink out, it won't mean a thing to us.

250.sent: We won't care that we're last and we won't care that there are no more stars.

252.sent: We're just dumb and lucky.” “Pure dumb luck,” he said.

255.sent: “How long ago was that?” asked Adrienne.

257.sent: Traveling on this ship.” Ray, he looked down at his hands, folded together in his lap, fingers interlaced.

259.sent: We were all quiet for a moment.

260.sent: Ray shrugged, then got up and left.

264.sent: More excuses were made, and after a few moments, only Adrienne and I were left sitting in the ballroom.

265.sent: She looked across the circle of couches at me.

268.sent: “How long have you been here?” “Not that long,” I said.

270.sent: Maybe a month or two.” “Why don't you know for sure?” she asked.

274.sent: How were you found?” “I was an engineer.” I explained how my ship had malfunctioned, no warning at all.

276.sent: “I don't know how Jefferson knew to find me there.” She nodded.

277.sent: “The ship I was on, I guess that's what happened, too.

278.sent: Some vital part broke, and... well, boom.

279.sent: It was all so fast.” She took a sip of her drink, plain water because, she had explained earlier, she had never liked the taste of alcohol, then fixed her gaze on me.

280.sent: “I'm going to figure it out,” she said.

282.sent: I'll figure it out, then I'm going to find a way home.” I paced my room that night, unable to sleep.

283.sent: The more I thought about it, the less sense the ship made.

284.sent: Worse, Adrienne had made this clear to me with a single question.

285.sent: I had spent weeks asking nothing, contentedly getting nowhere.

287.sent: Fact: It's too easy to fall into patterns.

288.sent: I resolved to break the pattern.

291.sent: “Has anyone ever left?” Adrienne looked at each of us in turn.

292.sent: Ray exchanged a glance with Zheng.

294.sent: “Now that you mention it, I haven't seen Alexis in days.

295.sent: I assumed he was indisposed.” Kishori nodded in agreement.

296.sent: I looked at Ray and raised an eyebrow.

298.sent: The approximate number of people at any given event is always the same.

299.sent: But we see new faces.” “You're sure it's not just some people being indisposed ?

301.sent: Zheng shook his head and picked up a handful of candied pecans from a little dish on the end table.

302.sent: “Keep adding people long enough, regardless, you get more overall.

303.sent: A couple people staying in their rooms, even if you switch out the people, won't make a difference.” He dropped the pecans back into the dish, one by one.

304.sent: “So where do they go?” Adrienne focused on Zheng.

306.sent: “Maybe a better question is, does anyone ever come back?” Ray and Zheng exchanged another glance.

308.sent: Sarah shrugged and sipped at her drink.

309.sent: After a moment, Ray said, “I don't think so.” “Are there patterns?” Adrienne asked.

310.sent: “Who leaves?” Again, there was an uncomfortable moment of silence.

312.sent: “You don't notice, do you.” Sarah looked indignant.

314.sent: But... well, no one important ever disappears, so it doesn't really matter, does it.” I could tell she was trying to remember whom she had known who had left, and failing.

316.sent: No one offered a different answer.

318.sent: Mission accomplished: Our routine insouciance had been disrupted.

320.sent: Even when the conversation returned to lighter tones, as it soon did, I dwelt on Adrienne's questions.

321.sent: From the looks on my companions' faces, I knew they were thinking the same.

322.sent: “How long have you been here?” The question, previously posed to me, was presented to the rest of our group (excluding Ray; Adrienne had been tactful enough to wait until he had gone for a refill, recalling the last time the subject was broached).

323.sent: Sarah, she tilted her head and tapped a finger on the side of her wine glass.

325.sent: Got to be months and months, at least.” “You were here before I was,” said Kishori, “and so was Tiffany.” I looked at Zheng; he shrugged.

326.sent: “Time passes in a weird way here.

327.sent: I kept track for a while—thirty-eight days—but after that... I guess I didn't see the point.” Fact: Some places are timeless.

330.sent: “The eleventh of a month or the seventeenth, whether it's Wednesday or Sunday, summer back on Earth or winter, it doesn't affect us here.” Tiffany nodded, but Kishori spoke before the other woman could.

331.sent: “Why are you so interested?” she asked Adrienne.

333.sent: “I don't want to be here forever.” “But we're not here forever,” objected Sarah.

336.sent: “We don't know how or why he left.

337.sent: Or where he went.” Zheng looked thoughtful.

338.sent: He picked up his glass, swirled the liquid around, took a sip, then set the glass back down.

339.sent: He glanced around at the rest of us.

340.sent: “Do you want to leave?” he asked.

341.sent: “Could you live anywhere else now?” I spoke up.

343.sent: “I wouldn't miss this, much.” No one else said anything.

344.sent: I watched Adrienne's eyes move from one face to the next.

345.sent: Zheng, he addressed me again, leaning forward with his elbows on his knees and an intense, steady gaze.

346.sent: “You think that,” he said, “but is it true?

347.sent: Would you be happy back in a normal life, working and living and crying in the drudgery of whatever the hell normal is these days?” I didn't answer.

348.sent: Fact: It's too easy to fall into patterns.

349.sent: Fact: I wasn't sure I wanted the dream stage to end.

352.sent: I sat sideways in the armchair, feet dangling over one arm, neck resting against the other, absently tracing invisible lines between the stars outside my window as I ruminated on the situation.

353.sent: The lightscreen had proved singularly unhelpful.

354.sent: I inspected the arrays of entertainment options—abstract, old-style flatscreens, engrossing VR flicks and action games, a selection of quondam bestsellers and a few recently released novels hoping to gain popularity.

355.sent: There was a schedule advertising upcoming on-ship events, such as dance classes, craft sessions, and discussion groups, and a list of dinner invitations for me to respond to.

356.sent: A menu of display options, allowing me to customize all the lightscreen's superficial characteristics.

357.sent: A simple contact system for communicating with other people on the ship.

359.sent: A methodical search of my two adjoining rooms, the ample closet space, and the attached bathroom facility had similarly provided no fodder.

360.sent: Furniture (dark wood, expensive, polished, no secret compartments), clothes, leftover tray of half-consumed food from the previous day's lunch, toiletries (complete with miniature bottles of sweet-smelling apricot honey lotion), lightscreen, me.

362.sent: I wanted to prove to Adrienne that I wanted solve the ship's mystery just as much as she did.

363.sent: I wanted to find something, anything, that would prove all this was normal and sane.

364.sent: I didn't want to think about disappearances and time and purposes and consequences.

366.sent: I cornered Adrienne at dinner that night.

367.sent: In one hand I balanced my plate of star-shaped crackers, globs of elegant dips and garnishes, little rolled balls of meats and cheeses stabbed through with spears of some pale green plant, and an array of other delectable, bite-sized items.

368.sent: My other hand pointedly steered Adrienne to a small table against a wall.

369.sent: She glared at me, but obediently let me pull her along.

370.sent: “Tell me,” I said, after we sat, “what you have found.” It wasn't a question.

371.sent: She gave me a grumpy look that informed me, quite clearly, of her current opinion of me.

372.sent: “Not if you're going to be rude about it.” I sighed.

373.sent: “Sorry.” I wasn't, not really, but I'd lie to get the conversation going.

374.sent: “I want to know.” I explained, in two brief sentences, my earlier impasse.

375.sent: “I don't know much,” she said, still annoyed but at least cooperative.

376.sent: She reviewed the information gleaned from our previous dinner conversations, adding, “I heard the captain say something yesterday, as I walking to the Pyrope Parlor.

377.sent: I was just coming up on a corner and he was around the other side, talking to a couple people, and they must not have known I was there.

378.sent: He said something about a wreck going well.

379.sent: And listen, when they came round the corner, Ray was with the captain.” The next time the captain stopped by our group, Tiffany tagging along (pretending that she, too, was a social butterfly who could mingle equally well with everyone), we were ready.

380.sent: “Is there a doctor on board?” asked Adrienne.

381.sent: “I've been having headaches.” It was a lie, but we needed information.

383.sent: “Down past the Emerald Lounge, second door on the left.

385.sent: Medical AI were even more expensive than the barkeep.

386.sent: I wondered how many people it treated.

387.sent: Had anyone on the ship ever fallen seriously ill?

390.sent: “I never thought about it.” Adrienne steepled her fingers and studied my face.

391.sent: “That doesn't answer my question,” she said.

392.sent: Adrienne only picked at her food.

395.sent: “At least have a drink,” said Sarah.

396.sent: “I find it takes the edge off.” “She doesn't drink, remember?” said Kishori.

398.sent: “One hundred and forty-seven is a magic number,” said Sarah.

400.sent: Well, we've got the perfect-size group right here.” Just enough for us all to recognize each other.

401.sent: Just enough for us all to be able to barely avoid killing each other.

403.sent: “If you dislike this place so much, why don't you do something about it?” “We can't,” said Ray.

404.sent: “What would we do?” Adrienne shook her head and made a sound of disgust.

405.sent: “You could force the captain to set down somewhere.

408.sent: If he still refuses, well, of all of us, isn't there someone who can drive a ship?” “That's murder,” objected Sarah.

410.sent: “Do you want to be stuck here for the rest of your life?” Sarah didn't reply.

411.sent: I shifted my feet in the plush green carpeting of the Emerald Lounge, looking out the windows at the stars.

412.sent: Times like that, running on less sleep than I should, alone because everyone else had had the sense to retire for the night, I had a tendency to get all meditative about the universe and my place in it.

413.sent: The stillness of the room contributed, as did the view.

414.sent: Black and more black, speckled by tiny points of light that flared up to break the emptiness, if only for a brief time.

415.sent: All of it was temporary, save for the black.

416.sent: That was tonight's melodramatic theme: the ephemeral nature of life.

418.sent: Everything to fade away, lost as dust and scattered atoms between the stars, and every one of us to be left as alone as the moment we were born.

419.sent: Thinking about that, I wondered if Sarah's theory was right after all.

420.sent: Some things in this world, we have to make them permanent ourselves.

421.sent: And Jefferson, he had done that.

422.sent: He had made us a constant.

423.sent: He made this ship—this life—a constant.

424.sent: The one thing that was known.

425.sent: The one thing that wouldn't change.

426.sent: Maybe everything we did, all the stories we told, maybe it was all lies.

427.sent: Maybe we'd never know each other, not truly, because we all hid behind the stories, creating the realities we wanted to see.

428.sent: But ultimately, this ship, its purpose, our purpose—did it matter?

429.sent: We each had our own theory.

431.sent: And all of us, we were permanent characters in each others' stories.

432.sent: Maybe that made us more real.

433.sent: Maybe it made us feel less alone.

434.sent: “Mind if I join you?” I turned to see Adrienne in the doorway.

435.sent: She smiled, then crossed the room to join me by the window, not waiting for an answer.

436.sent: “Some nights,” I said, “I can't see the meaning in any of it.

437.sent: All these things I do, they're just to pass the time until I die.” Adrienne looked at me, then back out through the window.

438.sent: “You don't see a meaning because there is no meaning,” she said.

439.sent: After all of it, as much as we feared being alone, we feared being vulnerable even more.

442.sent: In her hands was a bottle.

445.sent: Jefferson was in the Captain's Lounge, Fact: Sound is a vibration.

446.sent: The speed of sound in dry air at twenty degrees Celsius or sixty-eight degrees Fahrenheit is three hundred and forty-three meters per second, or one thousand one hundred twenty-five feet per second.

447.sent: “Up his dosage,” I heard the captain say.

448.sent: “I've got a replacement lined up.” I ran.

450.sent: I didn't want to be harvested.

451.sent: The last thing I remember, I was tearing down the corridors.

454.sent: In case of emergency, break glass.

456.sent: I'd put on a space suit, I'd get out of this ship, I'd find civilization again.

463.sent: Ray, he caught me as I pounded on the corridor walls, finding no glass to break.

464.sent: “Relax,” he told me, sliding a needle into my arm.

466.sent: He held me in his arms until I stopped flailing.
